fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The Eilenberg–Moore category induces the terminal decomposition of a monad

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The Eilenberg–Moore category together with its canonical adjunction is the terminal decomposition of a monad into adjoint functors. Hence there is a unique morphism from any decomposition to it, named the comparison functor.
Given a pair of adjoint functors F \dashv G, G is monadic if the corresponding comparison functor to \mathcal { C } ^{G \circ F} is an equivalence in the bicategory of decompositions.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The Kleisli category of a monad

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given a monad M : \mathcal { C } \to \mathcal { C } and two objects X, Y in \mathcal { C }, a Kleisli arrow from X to Y is simply any arrow X \to MY. This represents an algebra homomorphism from the free algebra generated by X to that of Y.

The identity Kleisli arrow is defined as \eta : X \to MX. The composition of f : X \to MY and g : Y \to MZ is given by X \xrightarrow {f} MY \xrightarrow {Mg} M^2 Z \xrightarrow { \mu } MZ. This forms a category whose objects are the objects of \mathcal { C }, as a formal symbol standing for the free algebra generated by those objects, and morphisms are Kleisli arrows. This is the Kleisli category \mathcal { C } _M.
